newsitem.title: USA: Prudential faces no more charges on partnerships.
newsitem.headline: Prudential faces no more charges on partnerships.

text.p: The investigation into the marketing and sale by Prudential Securities Inc of oil and gas limited partnerships known as the Energy Income Fund has ended without additional criminal charges, officials said Wednesday.
The investgation could be reopened if new evidence of criminal wrongdoing by individuals comes to light, U.S. Attorney Mary Jo White said in a statement.
Federal prosecutors began the investigation in late 1993 and a criminal complaint charging securities fraud was filed in October 1994.

At that time, a deferred prosecution agreement was filed stating the charges would be dropped if Prudential Securities paid $330 million into a special fund established by the Securities and Exchange Commission for investors who purchased limited partnerships. As part of the agreement, Prudential Securities had to admit its corporate wrongdoing and agree to the appointment of an independent ombudsman and outside counsel to insure its compliance. The firm will be monitored for compliance until October 1997.
